Crime and Punishment

You look at the sea, and it just hits you with sadness. What’s really annoying is that you actually feel sad! Honestly, it’s better to stay home. At least there, you can blame everyone else and avoid taking responsibility. I should’ve maybe gone on an adventure to the North Pole since I can’t stand drinking, and all that’s left is wine. I’ve tried it, but it’s not for me. 

Anyway, I heard Berg is taking people up in a big balloon next Sunday from the Yusupov Garden. Is that true? 

“Are you going to go?” 

“Me? No way,” Svidrigaïlov said, looking lost in thought. 

“What’s he on about? Is he serious?” Raskolnikov wondered. 

“The document didn’t hold me back,” Svidrigaïlov continued, deep in his own world. “It was my choice to stay here. Almost a year ago, Marfa Petrovna returned the document to me on my name day and even gave me a nice chunk of money. She had a lot of money, you know. She said, ‘You see how I trust you, Arkady Ivanovitch.’ You don’t believe she actually said that? But I managed the estate pretty well; people know me around here. I even ordered some books. Marfa Petrovna liked it at first, but then she got worried I’d study too much.” 

“Sounds like you really miss Marfa Petrovna.” 

“Miss her? Maybe. Honestly, I might. By the way, do you believe in ghosts?” 

“Which ghosts?”

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Svidrigaïlov reflects on his past and the influence of Marfa Petrovna while contemplating the idea of ghosts.
